Still, it is human perspective, ethical oversight, and creativity that unlock the real potential of AI. If you opt for AI-driven innovation, don’t just focus on deploying algorithms—keep your team members in the loop to ensure that teams guide, verify, and apply human context to machine outputs.  

So, by focusing on seamless collaboration between AI and humans, businesses can align speed with responsibility, driving innovation while managing risks. Ultimately, it’s the amalgamation of human governance and AI capabilities that defines long-term evolution. 

Final Takeaway 

I’m optimistic! When powered by knowledge and structured by guardrails, Vibe Coding can revolutionize how dev teams build. It empowers humans to focus on things machines cannot - define objective, map out strategies, and employ critical thinking. The key for quick-moving businesses lies in striking the right balance. 

So, if you’re considering integrating Vibe Coding, begin with pilot projects, capture all data, and keep humans in the loop. Well, the future isn’t humans vs. AI — it’s the seamless collaboration of AI with humans, vibing to design and develop more intelligent systems.

entry.title: From Exploration to Excellence: Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Community!

You've made the investment in SAP Business Technology Platform. You've implemented integrations, built extensions, and connected your enterprise landscape. But here's the question that keeps IT leaders up at night: Are you truly maximizing SAP BTP's potential, or are you leaving transformative value on the table?

For most organizations, the honest answer is somewhere in between—and that uncertainty is precisely the problem. Without a clear baseline of your current capabilities, it's nearly impossible to chart an effective course forward or justify additional resources to stakeholders who demand measurable results.

To tackle this challenge, SAP introduced the Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP at SAP TechEd 2025—a comprehensive technical evaluation designed to transform uncertainty into actionable insights. If you missed it during SAP TechEd, here are all the exciting details. Here's the On-Demand session of the SAP TechEd 2025 XP100v | Accelerate adoption of SAP Business Technology Platform with confidence.

 

What You'll Get: Immediate Value, Strategic Direction

You'll gain a precise understanding of your organization's maturity of SAP BTP utilization, allowing you to identify and address areas for improvement with tailored recommendations. Additionally, you'll align your platform strategy with broader business objectives, ensuring that every effort contributes to your digital transformation goals. Moreover, you'll uncover hidden operational efficiencies and innovative solutions that can drive tangible business value, elevating your role as a strategic tech leader within the organization.

  • Roadmap Clarity: Transform vague improvement intentions into a structured roadmap with prioritized actions based on your specific needs.
  • Investment Justification: Develop compelling business cases for additional SAP BTP investments, armed with concrete data on maturity levels and improvement opportunities, aligned with your overall business objectives.
  • Operational Efficiency: Uncover potential inefficiencies in how you're consuming SAP BTP services and discover opportunities to optimize SAP BTP utilization.
  • Innovation Acceleration: Identify new use cases and innovative solutions you haven't considered based on your maturity profile.

 

Getting Started: The Assessment Process

The online questionnaire takes only 10-15 minutes to complete, which is less time than your daily stand-up. No lengthy interviews or extensive documentation reviews—just focused questions that get to the heart of your implementation. Upon completion, you receive immediate scoring along with a comprehensive report.

  1. Complete the Questionnaire: Answer focused questions across five key dimensions in just 10-15 minutes.
  2. Receive Your Results: Get immediate feedback and access your comprehensive report in PDF to find areas for improvement and instant recommendations.
  3. Take Action: Use the tailored recommendations to act.

 

 

 

Maturity Levels Explained

The Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP is designed to provide organizations with a clear, current snapshot of how to utilize SAP BTP effectively. This snapshot is segmented into five distinct maturity levels, each representing different stages of adoption and integration within the organization. These levels serve as indicators of an organization's ongoing journey towards digital transformation and innovation. By understanding and leveraging these levels, organizations can strategically evolve their usage of SAP BTP, ensuring that they derive maximum value from the platform.

1. Getting Started: This initial phase involves early exploration of the platform, where learning and testing ideas occur in an ad hoc manner. Organizations at this level are in the discovery phase, familiarizing themselves with the platform's capabilities and potential.

2. Adoption: In this stage, foundations begin to form as growing platform adoption occurs, although key practices are still maturing. Organizations start to incorporate SAP BTP more consistently into their operations, paving the way for broader implementation.

3. Standardization: At this level, clear processes and shared approaches are established across teams, ensuring consistent and strategic SAP BTP usage. This marks a critical point where the platform becomes an integral part of the organization's technology stack, contributing to more streamlined and effective operations.

4. Scalable Execution: Here, SAP BTP is deployed reliably at scale, driving innovation across the organization. This stage reflects a higher level of maturity, where the platform is not only used but also leveraged to achieve strategic business objectives.

5. Center of Excellence: The pinnacle of SAP BTP maturity, this level signifies that the organization recognizes SAP BTP as a strategic driver of its business. Enterprise architecture, operations, and delivery capabilities are optimized around SAP BTP, fostering an environment of continuous innovation.

The Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP serves as a valuable tool for organizations to evaluate their current standing and plan for future growth. It not only aids in identifying areas for improvement but also provides actionable insights to enhance the platform's utilization, ultimately supporting the organization's continuous process of evolution and thriving in the digital landscape.

 

Why Act Now

The role of SAP Business Technology Platform in driving intelligent enterprises continues to expand, with new capabilities emerging regularly—from enhanced integration patterns to advanced AI agents.

Organizations with a clear understanding of their current maturity level can evaluate these innovations strategically, adopting what drives value while avoiding distraction. The objective is not only to assess your BTP maturity but also to create a continuous improvement cycle rather than being forced to react when gaps become critical.

In conjunction with the new Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP,  SAP BTP Adoption Phases are introduced on SAP BTP Guidance Framework as a beta version for SAP TechEd. This will provide a clear path to align the phases of SAP BTP adoption with SAP Activate Methodology. SAP Activate Methodology also offers additional common accelerators (e.g., project management templates) and an integrated tool chain (e.g. with SAP Cloud ALM) to run larger SAP implementation projects.

To illustrate the relationship between the Future Ready Enterprise Model, the new Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP, and the Adoption Phases, here’s a TAM of the process:

 

Your Next Steps: From Assessment to Action

Bharat Sandhu, CMO of SAP BTP, notes that developers struggle to effectively utilize AI due to difficulties in integrating it with business-specific data and processes, resulting in diminished benefits. Additionally, the time and cost of building applications, along with the challenge of managing fragmented systems, underscore the need for a more robust AI-powered development platform. To solve those challenges, knowing precisely where your organization stands today is crucial for maximizing the transformative potential of SAP BTP. The Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP is designed to deliver this insight, helping you determine if your organization is fully harnessing its capabilities.

Whether you're at the beginning of your SAP BTP journey or looking to optimize mature investments, this assessment provides a comprehensive technical baseline alongside the strategic clarity, objective data, and actionable recommendations you need to move forward with confidence.

Watch the SAP TechEd On-Demand Session: Watch the On-Demand session XP100v | Accelerate adoption of SAP Business Technology Platform with confidence for a demo of the Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP.

Engage with the Community: Join upcoming webinars and workshops where SAP experts and peers discuss assessment findings and share best practices for advancing BTP maturity.

Leverage Additional Resources: Explore the existing SAP BTP use cases and the corresponding SAP Discovery Center missions with accelerators.

Read about SAP Discovery Center Updates: Read this blog to learn all of the notable updates on SAP Discovery Center in preparation for SAP TechEd 2025. 

 

Take the first step by visiting SAP Discovery Center today and unlock the insights that will drive your next breakthrough🚀

entry.title: A Smarter Support Experience
entry.content:
Your support experience is evolving. Key changes and what you need to know.

As part of our ongoing efforts to make support from SAP smarter and easier for you, we have been piloting new ways to optimize the support experience and better connect you with the right channels and the right experts. We are excited to share that these improvements are now live. 

What’s changing 

As your entry point, the “Get Support” application has been enhanced to make it easier to create and manage your support cases. 

  • A clearer, unified navigation structure now guides you through case creation, with each step accessible from the left-hand pane. 
  • The detailed description field has been moved to the beginning of the process—helping you provide important context earlier and improving the quality of AI-driven recommendations. 
  • Improved UI consistency and AI disclosure messages to make the interface more transparent, intuitive, and ready for future innovation. 

In particular, the Incident Solution Matching (ISM) service has been further enriched with generative AI (GenAI) capabilities. Based on the information you provide, the service compiles relevant solutions and summarizes them into a single, easy-to-read answer—complete with links to the original knowledge articles used. 

The GenAI feature is being rolled out to customers in phases, starting with a limited group and expanding over time. It includes a feedback option to continuously refine your experience. 

When you create a case, you may receive a recommended priority based on your case details. This helps guide your selection so your case can reach the right experts and most suitable support channel, helping to enhance the overall resolution time. You remain in full control and can always adjust the priority to reflect your business impact or urgency. 

 

New customer view in 'Get Support' application

Set up your case for faster resolution 

To help ensure your case reaches the right experts as quickly as possible: 

  • Write a concise title for the issue that states the key symptom. 
  • Use the detailed description section to provide evidence, error messages, recent changes, and attempted fixes. 
  • Select the correct system that is affected by the technical issue you want to report 
  • Select the most accurate product, function, or component. 
  • Clearly describe the business impact, along with any workarounds in place 
  • Keep your case updated if conditions change and add feedback if you adjust the proposed priority. 

Thank you for partnering with us as we continue to transform support from SAP into an experience that is smarter and more effective for you.

entry.title: Joule in SAP Build Code can now create freestyle UI5 apps
entry.content:
Last year, we introduced the SAPUI5 extension for the Joule coding assistant in SAP Build Code and wrote about how to use it. Over time, it has received more features, like the AI-supported conversion of UI5 apps to TypeScript and setting up new pages and the respective navigation.

The latest improvement, available from November 2025, lets you create new freestyle UI5 apps according to your requirements. The feature is not absolutely groundbreaking, as there are other tools doing a similar job like the Easy-UI5 templates and the recently published UI5 MCP Server. But:

  1. It brings the functionality right to the fingertips of developers using SAP Build Code—no other tools needed.
  2. It extends the template capabilities beyond what the Easy-UI5 templates provide.
  3. Implementing it within the Build Code Joule environment yielded interesting insights and further improvements. More on this in my other article.

 

The feature

Joule makes specific features available using "slash commands". The new one is /ui5-create-app. When you open the Joule panel in SAP Build Code and start typing /ui5, you might see it suggested, as well as other UI5 features. But which commands appear depends on the context. While some are only available within UI5 apps, this new feature is only available when you are not in a UI5 app. It won't be available e.g. in a workspace which has a ui5.yaml at top-level, or when you have a UI5 controller open in the code editor!

 

Try it in a workspace with a CAP project at root level, so you see some of its magic immediately: as soon as you finish typing the slash command or select it from the suggestion list, another suggestion list with sample prompts comes up. These are based on the actual data structures of the CAP project.

This means you can simply select the desired entity and service, then the actual full prompt will automatically be entered into the field(but of course you can also write your own prompt!). This full prompt includes even more details than the short prompt in the suggestion list did.

Note that the prompt includes a concrete list of properties and the service URL. This information has been extracted from CAP using good old deterministic code—no Large Language Model (LLM) used. In fact, this is an area where AI would likely make up ("hallucinate") property names which do not actually exist. Acquiring all this information in advance in a deterministic way not only gives you the chance to review and adjust the prompt with little effort, but also leads to a more reliable functionality overall.

The paradigm: use LLMs (Large Language Models) where they excel—processing and "understanding" language—and use deterministic code for hard facts and well-defined operations, where possible. 

The AI part starts soon enough, when you submit this prompt. It proposes a specific app setup, highlighting the key choices for you to review. For example, it will suggest a sensible name (if you didn't provide one) or suggest the best location inside the project structure (which it knows from its context).

But you can do more than just review those parameters. A suggested version of the app has already been created behind the scenes, so you can scroll through the 30+ files listed in the box at the bottom and click those you want to preview. If the result already looks fine to you—perfect. Just press the "Accept Application" button and the app will be set up in your workspace.

Refining the app

But of course you are free to continue the conversation and tweak the result. The LLM in Joule will put its true strength at work, mapping its understanding of your request to what the underlying template can do. No need to type "change parameter x to value y": LLMs also understand you when you are less formal and direct. Look at the below screenshot for an example: it responds almost too compassionately to the developer who is "hesitant about new technologies" and recreates the app with changed parameters—using JavaScript instead of TypeScript. The user did not even mention the programming language specifically, but still the LLM decided that changing it would be the best way to accommodate the app code to the user's preferences.

At this stage, you can refine the setup of the initial app—within the limits imposed by the application template used behind the scenes, which only has limited degrees of freedom. We want this initial app to be robust and follow best-practice code. We also want those 30+ files to be created in one fast step. Hence the code is not written by AI, but by using predefined template files we are back in the world of traditional deterministic coding here. You have plenty of opportunity for using AI later on to extend the app from this solid starting point.

Joule is aware of its limits in this step, so it will not say "yes" to every request you throw at it. Asking for "a trillion tables" or other features beyond the template scope will be politely rejected.

Accepting the app

When the preview looks good and you have pressed the  button, the job of this /ui5-create-app assistant is done. After app setup has finished (which may take a while because the dependencies need to be installed), it concludes with hints how to continue, including instructions on how to start the app in your respective workspace setup.

The created application looks roughly like this, with a table and a detail form below. Note: only OData V4 services are supported at this time.

You get this kind of UI when you specify an OData V4 service and entity. If you don't, then there is just a generic "Hello World" success page instead.

Of course this UI structure might not be exactly what is desired in the app or even requested in the prompt, but this is what the template can do. When an OData service and entity but no properties are requested, then the tool tries to detect existing properties. If this fails, the table will be empty (no columns at all)—but Joule's success message should then mention this.

After creation

As the assistant suggests, please move to the other Joule assistants /ui5 and /ui5-create-page for developing the app further. In order to create more apps, reset the conversation with the  button at the top of the Joule pane.

Because /ui5-create-app knows that it cannot modify the app or re-create it, it will politely guide you to the options you have, no matter what your request is. It may even give instructions on how to achieve the given goal within a UI5 app, but it will not be able to modify the code and it will make this clear when needed.

AI Learnings

While there is not much more to say about this feature—simply try it!—there are some facts and learnings about its implementation! If you are curious, head over to the second part of this blog post: Inside Joule: Lessons from building an AI coding assistant for SAP Build.

entry.title: Inside Joule: Lessons from building an AI coding assistant for SAP Build
entry.content:
Flashback: the feature

This is a "making of" article about the implementation of the new /ui5-create-app slash command available within Joule in SAP Build Code. In short, this new feature enables a conversation between AI assistant and application developer about a new freestyle UI5 application to build, with a full-fledged best-practice application starting point as result.

To see screenshots of this feature in action and understand it better, feel invited to read my previous blog post. If you are just here for the background and AI-related learnings—go ahead!

 

General considerations

With open‑ended prompting, users aren’t restricted to predefined interactions. The user could ask for anything. In contrast to traditional programming, a prompt input field can’t be handled with a sprawling web of if/else logic trying to cover all possible use-cases. Attempting this will lead to a frustrating user experience where the user often gets an "I do not understand your request".

Some developers try to mimic this traditional programming pattern when crafting prompts and contexts for LLMs, telling an LLM "if the user asks for x, then answer y". Instead, as demonstrated below, tell the LLM what it can and cannot do and give it a goal to achieve. It's "smart" enough to figure out a suitable response to whatever the user will throw at it.

 

A fundamental choice

Looking at this specific feature in the specific environment, the implementation options on the table were (for a variety of reasons) these two:

  • Either just provide a system prompt (a prompt that is added behind the scenes in addition to what the user typed) without interfering with the specific prompts and replies entered during the conversation.
  • Or adopt a new way of creating an "agentic" multi-step execution plan. Similar to a guided activity, this would allow phases of data collection, possibly in different steps for different data, then an app creation step and so forth.

Surely "agentic" and "well-defined steps" sound good for app creation from a template, no? In fact, the initial implementation started like this, but it was soon apparent that this would neither provide the expected flexibility nor allow for a truly intelligent app creation experience. Defining phases in which to acquire specific information and having the application code created at a specific stage in this process did not feel right. The user would still feel like clicking through a traditional template creation process, as something specific was expected from the user at every stage, instead of giving the user the freedom to tweak every aspect at every stage. The true power of AI, on the other hand, would be totally underused.

But then again... just a system prompt and that's it? No file read access to explore the environment, no dynamically updated instructions? Is this enough for an intelligent coding assistant?

 

Creating an "AI agent" out of nothing

Consider the now common definition of an "AI agent" which has settled over the course of this year: it's nothing more than "an LLM with tools, called in a loop to achieve a goal". The chat conversation provided by Joule can be our loop, an application template with its parameters is the tool and the goal of assisting the developer to create an app can be stated in the system prompt. Of course a real autonomous agent would require the loop to run without user interaction, but for this feature a loop involving the user is just right.

The system prompt used for this feature literally includes: "You help users create new UI5 applications by analyzing their requirements and filling the project template parameters. [...] Your goal is to gather all necessary information to create a new UI5 application. The application will be generated from a template which has only one page and a hardcoded UI, but can optionally display data from an OData V4 service. [...] You cannot create the application yourself, but the user will see a preview...". There you have it: the goal and the tool!

It then goes on with some behavioral hints and of course a detailed description of what exactly the template parameters do. Finally, it requests each reply to contain a JSON object with the best choice of template parameters according to the current understanding of the user request. The JSON object could look like this example:

{

   "appNamespace": "com.myorg.myapp",

   "basePath": "/path/to/workspace",

   "createAppDirectory": true,

   "framework": "SAPUI5",

   "frameworkVersion": "1.136.0",

   "author": "John Doe",

   "oDataV4Url": "https://services.odata.org/TripPinRESTierService/(S(s5xrj1t51r41s3ooztsynysq))/",

   "oDataEntitySet": "Airports",

   "entityProperties": ["Name", "Address"],

   "runNpmInstall": true,

   "initializeGitRepository": true,

   "typescript": true

}

This JSON object is removed from the LLM response before displaying it, then the application is generated with these parameters, so the user can accept it or request changes. In an environment where tools with a well-defined interface like MCP servers are not enabled, this JSON object as part of the conversation is how the integration with the templating tool is achieved. It's basically a use-case-tailored alternative to MCP.  A note to make this very clear: this environment is not the official SAP Joule assistant running inside end-user applications, as it is now also being enabled for development by customers. Instead, it is a sort of predecessor implementation specifically available in SAP Build Code since spring 2024 and about to be replaced by advanced solutions. So do not draw conclusions about SAP Joule based on this article.

Some of these parameters in the JSON object are more important than others with regards to the user explicitly influencing them or having to accept them. Whether the app code is generated as TypeScript or JavaScript is something the user should not be surprised with after accepting the app! On the other hand, the author name, which is only written into package.json, can be reliably defaulted to the logged-in user name and also very easily changed later on if needed. Hence, the parameter descriptions explain not only what they do, but also how much the user should be bothered with them. As result, Joule usually does not even mention half of the parameters, thus keeping the conversation focused.

 

How to stop the agent

Regarding the state after the app was accepted, the prompt explains "AFTER the user has generated the application, you **MUST NOT** continue discussing parameters for generation, but rather [...] in particular by referring the user to the '/ui5' command for most requests or '/ui5-create-page' for adding pages to the app, because they are much better than you in developing features, as they have the capability to automatically select a suitable context of files.".

This means the transition in the overall process between refining parameters and "no more changes possible" is not a hardcoded step or denoted by changing the system prompt, but rather explained up-front. That's enough. Can you talk Joule into proposing another set of parameters after the app was accepted? Maybe. But its normal behavior is just right: it will explain that the app can not be created again without restarting the conversation. Nevertheless, there are also non-AI guardrails in place to prevent the app from being generated again, thus causing trouble.

All in all, we shape Joule’s behavior by explaining the templating tool and its limits, by stating the goal and desired behavior towards this goal, and by explaining the general flow, in particular the state after app acceptance. This is enough to guide it to a suitable reaction for whatever the user requests.

Even if the user insists like this:

 

Context, context, context!

To make the entire feature really user-friendly, however, it is not sufficient to write a good prompt, but the context must also provide enough information to the LLM to allow for informed decisions. Hence, information like the list of project root files and folders, whether a Git repository is present, plus CAP service/entity/property info, and more, are gathered (e.g. using the @sap-ux/project-access package). This knowledge is provided as prompt context behind the scenes or used in another way (like as content of the suggested prompts). This makes Joule aware of the environment it acts in, leading to better responses, like automatically avoiding app names that would conflict with existing folder names.

Agentic coding assistants like Cline, GitHub Copilot, Cursor etc. usually have the ability to read files and execute shell commands as needed to understand their environment. In this pure user request + LLM response environment this might have been a bit harder to build. Basically, more tools could have been defined, e.g. by describing other JSON object structures for invoking them. But control would not so easily return to the LLM until after the user has entered another prompt. Or, there could have been one "preprocessor" LLM request asking for needed files, like it is done for the other /ui5* commands.

But for a narrow scenario like app creation this wasn't necessary. Collecting the most relevant information up front not only provides sufficient context, but also improves performance and reliability by avoiding repeated tool calls and unpredictable LLM loops.

 

In-response prompting

The real-world context, however, changes over time. Specifically, once the app is created and accepted, there are new additional files present.

When developing the UI5 MCP server, we observed that the agentic AI tool (e.g. Cline) using the MCP server often decided to inspect the new app directory tree after creation, causing several LLM roundtrips which cost time and tokens. Or it would run "npm install" again, even though it had already been executed. Or it would make specific coding errors very often in subsequent modifications.

To avoid this, we extended the response of the MCP server after creating the app. Normally, it contains just the success message. But now it includes a full list of generated files, it states that "npm install" was already executed and it instructs how to prevent those coding errors. Basically, the MCP server response added further updated instructions to the conversation context.

Exactly the same principle was applied in this new Joule feature. While there is no autonomous agent loop in this case which would inspect the new files, the knowledge which files were created can be valuable for the conversation with the user. And while the/ui5-create-app command doesn't modify any code after app creation (thus avoiding the coding issues), facts like whether "npm install" was already executed, or whether the created UI5 Table in the MainView is lacking any columns, are useful for giving the user hints how to continue. Therefore, the context is extended by adding a hidden message to the conversation history.

 

Traditional coding has its place(s)

In addition to the process of context collection, deterministic coding is also used after the app has been accepted by the user for making the app consumption as smooth as possible. When inside a CAP project, it for example ensures that the cds-plugin-ui5 is added as dependency. This allows the UI5 tooling, including TypeScript transpilation of the UI5 app when needed, to run as part of the "cds watch" or "npm start" script of the CAP project itself.
 
Also, this dependency and all the UI5 app dependencies need to be installed. Unfortunately, there is a wide range of options and specific setups which might be used for dependency management in the already existing app. Probably npm? With or without workspaces? yarn? pnpm? Others? The code detects what is used and tries to cover the 95% case. The initial setup might not be complete in every scenario, but for most users it will “just work,” providing a good developer experience.
AI is fine and all, but sometimes one has to go the extra mile and do some coding.
 

Key takeaways

  • Use deterministic code where reasonable (because the space of possibilities is bounded and a deterministic and quick result is beneficial) .
  • Use LLMs for language understanding or dealing with an unpredictable range of possible requests.
  • Don't try to "program" the LLM with an if/else prompt, but treat it like an intelligent human: state the goal, options and boundaries—and let it decide on its own.
  • Provide solid pre-collected context so the LLM can make good decisions reliably.

 

P.S.:

For those who prefer graphics over text to gain an understanding of something, here is a depiction of the overall information flow inside this feature.

entry.title: SAP-RPT-1: A Revolutionary Tabular ML Model and OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance
entry.content:
Note: This blog discusses SAP-RPT-1 model, the enterprise version of the ConTextTab / SAP-RPT-1-OSS model architecture. The underlying technology is detailed in the ConTextTab research paper published by SAP, with an open-source implementation available as ConTextTab on Hugging Face and GitHub.

The Challenge: Traditional Tabular ML's Security Dilemma

In the world of enterprise machine learning, tabular data represents the backbone of business intelligence from customer analytics to financial forecasting. However, traditional tabular ML approaches have long faced a fundamental security challenge: the need for extensive fine-tuning on customer data.

When organisations deploy conventional ML models, they must:
- Fine-tune models using sensitive customer data, permanently modifying model weights
- Store customer information within model parameters, creating privacy risks
- Manage complex security frameworks to protect against data poisoning, model inversion, and membership inference attacks
- Navigate compliance requirements while maintaining model performance

This creates a paradox: the more effective the model becomes through fine-tuning, the greater the security risks it introduces.

Enter SAP-RPT-1: Redefining Tabular Machine Learning

The Breakthrough: In-Context Learning for Tabular Data

SAP-RPT-1 represents a paradigm shift in tabular machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. Built on the principle of In-Context Learning (ICL), SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance without ever modifying its core model weights.

How SAP-RPT-1 Works: A Security-First Architecture

Unlike traditional models that require fine-tuning, SAP-RPT-1 operates through a fundamentally different mechanism:

  1. Customer provides data (tables) examples as context
  2. Model processes examples in real-time without storing or learning from them
  3. Predictions are made based on patterns identified in the provided context
  4. Customer data is immediately discarded after prediction completion

This approach delivers two critical advantages:
- Superior performance through semantic understanding of tabular relationships
- Inherent security advantages through its ephemeral processing approach, addressing several traditional ML vulnerability categories.

The Technical Innovation: Seven Pillars of Security-by-Design

SAP-RPT-1 revolutionary approach is built on seven fundamental characteristics that naturally eliminate most machine learning security risks:

1. Specialized Architecture for Tabular Data

SAP-RPT-1 is fundamentally a classification and regression model designed specifically for structured data, not a Large Language Model. This focus makes it subject to the OWASP ML Top 10 security framework rather than LLM-specific vulnerabilities, providing a clearer security assessment pathway.

2. In-Context Learning vs. Traditional Fine-Tuning

The core innovation lies in SAP-RPT-1 learning approach:
- Traditional Fine-tuning: Permanently modifies model weights using customer data, creating persistent security risks
- SAP-RPT-1 ICL: Uses customer data as contextual examples within the input, without modifying any model parameters
- Security Advantage: Eliminates risks associated with model weight manipulation and data persistence

3. Enterprise API-First Security Model

- Fully managed API service: SAP handles all infrastructure, security, and model management while customers interact exclusively through secure, authenticated API endpoints
-  Enterprise-grade security: Leverages SAP's proven security frameworks and compliance standards to safeguard SAP-RPT-1, while the base architecture remains transparently published through the open-source SAP-RPT-1-OSS version
- Controlled environment: All predictions occur within SAP's secure infrastructure

4. Customer Data Dependency as a Security Feature

SAP-RPT-1 ICL architecture creates an inherent security advantage:
- No standalone inference: Model requires customer-provided historical examples for every prediction
- Customer data control: Prediction quality directly depends on customer-provided context
- Reduced poisoning risk: Traditional attacks like model poisoning and data poisoning become significantly limited
- Contextual relevance: Model can only make predictions within the scope of provided examples

 5. Ephemeral Processing Architecture

Every SAP-RPT-1 inference follows a secure, temporary processing model:
- Memory-only processing: Customer data exists solely during the inference request
- No weight updates: Model parameters remain completely unchanged throughout operation
- Zero persistence: No traces of customer information remain in the model

6. Enterprise-Grade SAP Management

As a SAP-provided service, SAP-RPT-1 benefits from comprehensive enterprise security controls:
- Supply chain security: Direct SAP control over model development, training, and distribution
- Model integrity: Protection against unauthorised modifications and tampering
- Data governance & compliance:   SAP ensures that all data used to train its Foundation Model follows strict regulations to protect privacy and meet legal standards. SAP has robust security policies to manage data safely when developing its applications.
- Quality assurance: Professional model validation and continuous security testing

7. Secure Semantic Processing Pipeline

SAP-RPT-1 employs a mathematically based data processing approach that eliminates code execution risks:

All inputs (strings, numbers, dates, etc.) are transformed into embeddings (vector representations of the data), and these embeddings undergo pure mathematical transformations within the model with no code execution occurring during data processing, only mathematical operations on numerical vectors: Inputs (e.g., strings, numbers, dates) → Vector Embeddings → Mathematical Operations → Prediction Result.

Security guarantees:
- No code execution pathways in data processing
- Pure mathematical tensor operations throughout the pipeline
- Semantic understanding without security vulnerabilities
- Input sanitization through numerical conversion

SAP-RPT-1 & OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance

With SAP-RPT-1 architecture established, we can now examine how these design principles address the industry-standard OWASP ML Top 10 security framework. This assessment demonstrates that SAP-RPT-1 innovative approach doesn't just match traditional security measures, it fundamentally eliminates most attack vectors entirely.

SAP RPT-1 & OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance Overview

OWASP ML Top 10Risk Applicability to SAP RPT-1Risk Assessment Technical RationaleSecurity Status
ML01: Input Manipulation AttackApplicableMinimal exposure due to customer-controlled data model

Customers provide their own contextual examples, significantly reducing adversarial input scenarios. Risk limited to compromised customer environments.

Customer Managed
ML02: Data Poisoning AttackNot ApplicableArchitecture prevents traditional data poisoning

In-Context Learning does not modify model weights. Customer data serves only as contextual input during inference, with no persistent model updates.

Inherently Protected
ML03: Model Inversion AttackNot ApplicableNo sensitive training data to extractCustomer data is ephemeral and not embedded in model weights. No gradient information exposed through API.Inherently Protected
ML04: Membership Inference AttackNot ApplicableSAP regulated training data eliminates attack vectorNo customer data persists in model, eliminating membership inference opportunities.Inherently Protected
ML05: Model TheftNot ApplicableSAP-managed infrastructure prevents model parameter accessSAP-RPT-1 is provided and managed within SAP's secure infrastructure. Customers access only the API endpoint, never the model parameters . Further since customer provided context is not saved in model due to ICL, model theft has no impact on customersInherently Protected
ML06: AI Supply Chain AttacksNot ApplicableSAP as trusted model provider eliminates supply chain riskSAP is the official model provider with direct control over development, training, and distribution. No third-party supply chain vulnerabilities.Inherently Protected
ML07: Transfer Learning AttackNot ApplicableNo transfer learning in deployment architectureIn-Context Learning eliminates transfer learning attack vectors entirely..Inherently Protected
ML08: Model Skewing ApplicableCustomer data quality responsibilityPotential for unintentional bias in customer-provided data. Model leverages  patterns present in contextual examples, requiring customer awareness and data curation.Customer Managed
ML09: Output Integrity AttackApplicableStandard API security controls applyRisk can be mitigated through conventional authentication and authorization mechanisms.Customer Managed
ML10: Model PoisoningNot ApplicableImmutable model architecturePre-trained model weights remain completely unchanged during operation. Customer data cannot modify base model behaviour or parameters.Inherently Protected

The Results: A New Standard for Secure ML

SAP-RPT-1 Security Achievement

The OWASP ML Top 10 compliance reveals SAP-RPT-1 remarkable security profile:

Inherent Protection Against 7 out of 10 Major Threats
SAP-RPT-1 In-Context Learning architecture provides built-in protection against most ML security risks. Unlike traditional systems that require extensive security hardening, SAP-RPT-1 design reduces the likelihood of most attack vectors by default.

Standard Controls for Remaining Risks
The three-remaining low-risk areas (Input Manipulation, Model Skewing, and Output Integrity) are addressed through conventional security measures that organisations typically already have in place:
- Input validation and API security controls
- Customer data governance
- Standard authentication and authorization mechanisms

Customer Empowerment Through Data Control
Rather than creating security burdens, SAP-RPT-1 empowers customers by giving them direct control over model behaviour through their own data, while eliminating the risks associated with traditional model training.

References:
- OWASP ML Security Top 10
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Paper
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Model
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Github
- SAP-RPT-1 Model FAQ
- Know more on SAP-RPT-1 Model

entry.title: AFSUG & SAP: A New Era of Support — Join Our Executive Series and Onsite Event in Cape Town
entry.content:
AFSUG & SAP: A New Era of Support — Join Our Executive Series and Onsite Event in Cape Town

Together with AFSUG, the African SAP User Group, SAP’s Customer Support organization is launching a series of high-impact remote sessions — all leading up to an exclusive onsite event in Cape Town in March 2026. This program gives customers a unique opportunity to learn directly from SAP executives and experts, discover the future of support, and experience how AI, automation, and preventative practices are reshaping SAP’s entire support landscape. Whether you want to understand SAP’s proactive support strategy, get hands-on with the latest digital experiences, or explore agentic AI in real customer scenarios — this series is built for you.

Why This Series Matters

SAP Support has evolved far beyond “break/fix.” Today, it is:

  • A strategic advantage, not an insurance policy
    SAP customers choose us because we help them run better, scale smarter, and stay ahead.
  • Preventive and predictive by design
    Programs like Black Friday / Cyber Monday Readiness demonstrate how SAP reduces risk before issues arise.
  • AI-powered, human-backed
    Agentic AI, prescriptive guidance, and intelligent digital entry points give customers immediate access to insights and the right expertise.
  • Embedded across the entire lifecycle
    Support is now a built-in value multiplier — from onboarding to transformation to continuous optimization.
  • Customer outcomes at the center
    Stability, performance, resilience, and continuous improvement aren’t extras — they’re expectations.
  • A blueprint for operationalizing AI
    SAP Customer Support is the frontrunner in adopting agentic AI inside SAP — and showing customers how to scale AI safely and practically in their own environments.

Join our experts as they unpack these themes in four remote sessions — each one providing unique insights and previews of what awaits at the onsite event in Cape Town.

Remote Session Series

1. November 27, 2025 — 3–4 PM CET / 4-5 PM SAST

From Reactive to Proactive: How SAP’s Support Strategy & Agentic AI Are Reshaping the Future

Speaker: Stefan Steinle, EVP & Head of Customer Support & Cloud Lifecycle Management, SAP SE

Support is shifting from reactive problem-solving to strategic enablement. Stefan Steinle will walk attendees through SAP’s future support strategy — one that is predictive, preventative, and deeply infused with agentic AI.

You’ll learn:

  • How SAP is moving toward proactive and preventative support models
  • How agentic AI analyzes telemetry, detects risks, and takes safe autonomous action
  • How disciplines from BF/CM Readiness are expanding into daily operations
  • A live demo on proactive support identifying “Go-Live endangered” situations
  • A first look at what awaits at the Cape Town onsite event — including Support Accreditation

👉Register now to secure your place.

2. December 11, 2025 — 3–4 PM CET / 4-5 PM SAST

Reinventing Support – Self-Services, Real-Time Assistance & the Power of AI

Speaker: Mohammed Ajouz, SVP & Global Head of Technical Support, SAP Americas

Traditional support is being reinvented. Mohammed Ajouz will showcase how SAP delivers intelligent, connected, and customer-centric services.

In this session, you’ll explore:

  • Smarter, always-available self-services
  • Live channels for real-time engagement
  • Agentic AI that supports — and acts — on your behalf
  • How AI and LLMs transform knowledge, case resolution, and insights

You’ll also get a preview of the onsite workshops and simulations — and how to earn the SAP Support Accreditation Certificate in Cape Town.

👉Register now to secure your place.

3. January 21, 2026 — 3–4 PM CET / 4-5 PM SAST

SAP Cloud ALM as Your Transformation Execution Platform

Speaker: Sören Ruder, SVP & CPO, Global Head of Customer Experience & Solutions, SAP SE

Transformation succeeds when tools work together — not in silos. This session shows how SAP Cloud ALM unifies processes, architecture, testing, and operations into a single AI-infused orchestration layer.

Learn how Cloud ALM:

  • Aligns Signavio processes directly with project scope
  • Synchronizes landscape models from SAP LeanIX
  • Coordinates manual and automated testing
  • Orchestrates ABAP and non-ABAP change processes
  • Uses intelligent event processing to reduce noise and automate remediation
  • Delivers real-time dashboards with embedded analytics

Sören Ruder will also preview deep-dive workshops happening onsite in Cape Town.

👉Register now for the January session.

4. February 26, 2026 — 3–4 PM CET / 4-5 PM SAST

Intelligent Front Door Thinking

Speaker: Michelle Lewis-Miller, Head of SAP Support Digital Experience & Voice of Customer, SAP SE

Every customer journey starts with a digital front door — and SAP is reinventing it.

This session includes:

  • Live demos of SAP for Me, the Get Support App, and the SAP Support Portal
  • Insights into personalization, streamlined access, mobility, and new navigation patterns
  • The debut of the SAP Support Accreditation Program

This is your best opportunity to get ready for certification onsite in Cape Town.

👉Register now for the February session.

🌍March 26, 2026 — Onsite in Cape Town, South Africa

AFSUG & SAP: From Insights to Impact

All remote sessions lead to this highly interactive onsite event — bringing together SAP executives, experts, and customers for a full day of hands-on learning, networking, and certification.

Onsite Highlights:

  • Keynote by Stefan Steinle: The Future of Support — Intelligent, Preventive, and Built for the Cloud Era

  • Multiple expert deep-dives on:

    • SAP for Me & Built-In Support
    • Self-Services, Live Channels & AI
    • Preventive Support & Agentic AI
    • SAP Cloud ALM and the Integrated Toolchain
  • Meet-the-Expert stations
  • Direct networking with SAP executives
  • SAP Support Accreditation — completed onsite with printed certificate

This is the moment where everything comes together — strategy, demos, hands-on labs, customer stories, and the opportunity to connect directly with the people shaping the future of support.

👉Registration opens soon — reserve the date now.

Join Us for the Full Journey

These remote sessions and the Cape Town onsite event offer an exceptional opportunity to:

  • Learn from SAP’s top executives
  • See agentic AI in action
  • Strengthen your SAP expertise
  • Network with industry peers
  • Earn your official SAP Support Accreditation

Don’t miss your chance to be part of this evolution.
Register for the sessions, mark your calendar for Cape Town — and join us as we shape the next era of SAP Support together.

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 2 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: How Data, AI, and Agents are Changing Supply Chain Planning

In the discussion about the future of supply chain management, one area is increasingly at the center: planning. Supply chain planning not only affects operational efficiency, but directly influences a company’s service quality, fixed capital and responsiveness. Our joint study from SAP Business Consulting and Kühne Logistics University clearly shows that companies that are already planning proactively today can avoid bottlenecks, optimize costs, and exploit potential in a targeted manner.

Supply chain planning is the central lever for anticipating problems before they arise. Companies that anticipate bottlenecks and proactively manage capacity, inventory and resources avoid hectic “fire fighting” in day-to-day operations. Planning thus acts as an early warning system that not only enables stable service, but also more efficient use of resources and proactive action. Effective planning also requires seamless integration and evaluation of a variety of internal and external data sources – from granular sales data to basic economic data, to production, procurement, and distribution plans. Different planning levels and horizons need to be connected, and this is where there are huge opportunities for artificial intelligence that can process data volumes, identify patterns, and improve predictions. Advanced planning processes will become a matter of course over the next ten years. If you do not achieve at least a modern, integrated planning level by 2035, you risk not only a competitive disadvantage, but also the loss of operational control capability.

Our survey of supply chain decision-makers (see figure) provides a clear picture of the future. Many expect planning to be much simpler and more intuitive in 2035 than today. More than half expect generative AI and GPT models to have a significant impact on planning processes, and much of it sees data quality as a critical factor in planning decisions. In addition, many expect the breakthrough of new AI-powered forecasting tools that incorporate additional data sources and significantly improve demand planning. Around a quarter expect advanced risk analysis to provide the ability to proactively detect and mitigate disruptions.

However, the status quo shows how big the gap between aspirations and reality is. Only a small number of companies rated their planning as mature in our survey. Similarly, few are actively experimenting with GenAI or GPT applications in the planning environment. Only a minority has very accurate planning data harmonized from different sources. Highly automated demand planning with minimal human intervention is the exception, as are planning systems that provide clear recommendations for action in the event of disruptions. This discrepancy shows that the path to truly modern, intelligent planning is still long and requires targeted investment, clear priorities and structured action.

In order to close this gap, different approaches must be pursued. Companies where planning is a strategic core process or requires very individual processes can realize enormous potential with agent-based AI. With the advent of new agency tools, most repetitive, error-prone work is automated, allowing planners to focus on value-added analytics and decisions. Companies with standardized processes and a low strategic relevance of planning will be able to procure their planning function more as a service in the future. Technology and platform models could enable true end-to-end planning across company boundaries for the first time. Simulations and digital twins will also play a growing role. Although these often fail today due to complexity, modeling effort, and scalability, AI-powered modeling agents could significantly accelerate and improve the accuracy of simulation creation and updates in the future, making their use more practical in larger networks.

Regardless of the individual target image, there are measures that every company should tackle immediately (“no-regret moves”). This includes building robust data governance and harmonizing master data as the foundation for any data-driven planning. Unfortunately, the principle of “garbage in, garbage out” also applies with AI: without high-quality data, even the best AI system cannot deliver meaningful value. A consistent, company-wide IBP system enabling a S&OP process provides the basis for a common planning goal. Initial pilot projects with agent-based sales forecasting help gather experience with AI-powered planning approaches. Finally, it is important to actively link existing planning platforms, such as SAP IBP, with AI services to unlock integration potential early on.

Supply chain planning is now more important than ever and will become a key differentiator between successful companies and those left behind by 2035. The technologies to make planning smarter, faster, and more resilient already exist – but they must be combined with clear goals, a resilient data foundation, and organizational readiness for change. Those who lay the foundations today will not only be able to plan faster and more precisely tomorrow but can also act strategically before others can even react.

Figure: Results of an online survey of 119 SC managers with people responsibility, conducted on 01/2025 as part of a joint SAP KLU study

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (Kühne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future”.
